name: title
text: Two decorators. One simple rule. Let me show you how dioxide keeps business logic and infrastructure apart.

name: show_ports
text: First, the ports. These are just Python protocols. They define what your app needs, a notifier and an audit log, without saying how.

name: show_service
text: Now the service. It uses at-service because business logic never changes between environments. Order Processor depends on the ports, not on Slack or Postgres.

name: show_prod_adapters
text: Here are the production adapters. Each one uses at-adapter-dot-for with a profile. Slack Notifier handles notifications. Postgres Audit Log handles compliance. They are wired to the production profile.

name: show_test_adapters
text: And the test adapters. Same ports, different profile. These are fast in-memory fakes. No network, no database. Just lists that record what happened.

name: run_prod
text: Lets run with the production profile. The container scans adapters, resolves the service, and injects Slack and Postgres automatically.

name: run_test
text: Now the test profile. Same service, same code path. But now it uses the fakes. No infrastructure needed. The assertions run against in-memory data.

name: closing
text: At-service for logic that never changes. At-adapter-dot-for for infrastructure that does. That is the only rule you need.
